diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: A highly infectious viral illness known to cause fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a characteristic rash.

diagnoses.name: Rubella
diagnoses.description: Also known as German measles, it is a contagious viral infection best known by its distinctive red rash.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's more common in children. The symptoms include fever, rash, eye inflammation (conjunctivitis), and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet fever
diagnoses.description: A disease resulting from a group A streptococcus (group A strep) infection, known for a fine red rash.

diagnoses.name: Drug reactions
diagnoses.description: Adverse reactions to drugs can include a range of symptoms including fever, rash, leukocytosis, and sometimes conjunctivitis.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono or the kissing disease, it's an infection with the Epstein-Barr virus. It may cause fever, sore throat, fatigue, and/or a rash.

diagnoses.name: Zika virus
diagnoses.description: A virus transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes causing fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis.

diagnoses.name: Chikungunya
diagnoses.description: A viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain. Other symptoms may include headache, muscle pain, joint swelling, or rash.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of your skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Often, it starts with flu-like symptoms, followed by a painful rash that spreads and blisters.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein purpura
diagnoses.description: A disease affecting the blood vessels, characterized by purplish spots on the skin, abdominal pain, and sometimes kidney involvement. Rash and kidney symptoms are common.

diagnoses: Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Parvovirus B19 infection (erythema infectiosum, fifth disease)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's predominantly seen in children. The symptoms you've described are characteristic, especially when seen in children.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Lip erythema, lip cracking, and rash can be indicative of this condition.

diagnoses.name: Exfoliative Cheilitis
diagnoses.description: A condition that leads to inflammation and peeling of the lips, which can cause the symptoms mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can cause a wide range of symptoms including rash and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: An infection that can occur in people who have strep throat. It's characterized by a bright red rash on the body, accompanied by fever. The lip symptoms mentioned can also be observed.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reactions
diagnoses.description: Adverse reactions to medications can cause a variety of skin manifestations, including maculopapular rash, as well as potentially affecting the lips and causing changes in white blood cell counts.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often referred to as mono, this disease is usually caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). Symptoms can include rash, leukocytosis, along with fatigue and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: A highly contagious viral infection causing a total-body skin rash and flu-like symptoms. It can also affect the mucous membranes, potentially leading to symptoms affecting the lips.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Deficiency in zinc can lead to a range of symptoms, including those affecting the skin and mucosal membranes, which might present as lip cracking or rash.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Multiforme
diagnoses.description: An acute, self-limited, and sometimes recurring skin condition considered to be a hypersensitivity reaction associated with certain infections, medications, and other various triggers. It's characterized by distinctive target-like lesions, but can also present with symptoms affecting the lips and an overall rash.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Infectious causes (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C-related cryoglobulinemia)
Viral Infection (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr Virus)

diagnoses.name: Viral pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium caused by a viral infection, often presenting with acute chest pain, fever, and possibly delirium in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial pericarditis
diagnoses.description: An infectious pericarditis caused by bacteria, presenting with acute chest pain, fever, delirium, and can lead to atrophic scarring if not treated properly.

diagnoses.name: Connective tissue diseases
diagnoses.description: Diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or rheumatoid arthritis that can cause pericarditis, fever, delirium, atrophic scarring, and proteinuria due to kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculous pericarditis
diagnoses.description: A form of pericarditis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis leading to chest pain, fever, delirium, and proteinuria might occur due to associated kidney damage.

diagnoses.name: Uremic pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium associated with renal failure, which can cause fever, acute chest pain, delirium, and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Malignancy
diagnoses.description: Cancers, particularly lymphoma or lung cancer that has metastasized to the pericardium, can cause acute pericarditis, fever, delirium, and atrophic scarring.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A lupus-like syndrome triggered by certain drugs, presenting with symptoms such as pericarditis, fever, and in rare cases, delirium. Proteinuria and atrophic scarring can also occur depending on the severity and treatment response.

diagnoses.name: Post-cardiac injury syndrome
diagnoses.description: Syndrome that occurs after heart injury (post-myocardial infarction, post-pericardiocentesis or post-cardiac surgery) and can include acute pericarditis, fever, and in severe cases, delirium.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic fever
diagnoses.description: A disease that can develop after a streptococcal infection, causing inflammation in the heart (including acute pericarditis), fever, and in severe cases delirium. Chronic cases may lead to atrophic scarring.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect any organ but primarily affects the lungs and lymph glands. It can cause pericarditis, fever, and atrophic scarring. Proteinuria occurs if the kidneys are involved.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including skin manifestations like atrophic scarring and potential for follicular hyperkeratosis, arthropathy, acute pericarditis, and hematological abnormalities including leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Dermatomyositis presents with characteristic skin changes, which might include follicular hyperkeratosis and atrophic scarring. It can also cause muscle weakness, arthropathy, and occasional cardiac involvement. Leukopenia may be secondary to the disease itself or as a result of immunosuppressive treatment.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease shares characteristics of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis - including arthropathy, skin changes akin to atrophic scarring and potentially follicular hyperkeratosis, as well as pericarditis and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.rationale: Scleroderma can cause skin thickening and atrophic scarring. While less common, it can also lead to follicular hyperkeratosis, and systemic involvement could explain arthropathy, acute pericarditis, and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily known for its severe arthropathy, RA can also lead to systemic complications including pericarditis. Follicular hyperkeratosis and atrophic scarring can occur, albeit less commonly, and leukopenia can emerge, especially in the context of Felty's syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: This form of arthritis associated with psoriasis could explain arthropathy and skin changes, potentially mimicking follicular hyperkeratosis and atrophic scarring. Psoriatic arthritis does not typically cause acute pericarditis or leukopenia directly, but systemic inflammation or treatments could potentially lead to these presentations.

diagnoses.name: Adult-onset Still's disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare inflammatory disorder that can feature arthropathy, skin rash which may present as atrophic scarring in chronic cases, and leukopenia. Acute pericarditis is also a potential feature.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Lyme disease can cause arthropathy, and in its late stages, can lead to skin changes that may be confused with atrophic scarring. Leukopenia and acute pericarditis are less common but possible manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis is known for its ability to affect multiple organ systems, potentially leading to skin manifestations that could include atrophic scarring, arthropathy, acute pericarditis, and leukopenia as part of its hematologic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) Infection
diagnoses.rationale: Advanced HIV infection can lead to a wide range of dermatological manifestations, potential articular syndromes mimicking arthropathy, cardiopulmonary complications including pericarditis, and leukopenia due to the impact on the immune system.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as fever, arthropathy (joint pain), skin lesions including atrophic scarring, nephritis (kidney inflammation), and acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Although more commonly associated with chronic joint inflammation, this condition can also lead to systemic symptoms including fever, and in rare cases, can cause pericarditis and nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues, it can also cause kidney problems (nephritis), arthralgia or arthritis (joint problems), and in some cases, pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory condition known for causing skin rash and muscle weakness can also lead to systemic symptoms, including joint issues (arthropathy), fever, and occasionally, complications such as pericarditis and nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease shares characteristics with other systemic autoimmune diseases like lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis and can present with a combination of symptoms including fever, joint pain, skin changes, acute pericarditis, and kidney inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: This infection of the inner heart lining can cause fever, joint pain (arthropathy), and in severe cases can lead to pericarditis. It can indirectly affect the kidneys, leading to nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: A group of disorders that involve inflammation of blood vessels, which can cause symptoms like fever, arthropathy, renal (kidney) involvement such as nephritis, and complications including pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis can cause joint pain, fever in some cases, and has been associated with complications that might mimic the symptoms listed, though it is a less common explanation.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: This condition, which can follow infections, typically presents with arthritis, but can also involve other symptoms like fever. Skin manifestations, heart, and kidney involvement are less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known as a respiratory disease, TB can have systemic manifestations including fever, kidney problems (nephritis), and in rare cases, can cause acute pericarditis and articulate manifestations.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (with concurrent medical conditions causing other symptoms)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., Viral or Bacterial infections that can cause acute pericarditis and pleural effusion)
Epilepsy (secondary to CNS involvement from systemic disease)

diagnoses.name: Selective IgA Deficiency
diagnoses.description: An immunodeficiency disorder characterized by an inability to produce adequate amounts of Immunoglobulin A (IgA), leading to increased susceptibility to infections and possible associations with malabsorption and autoimmune conditions.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by low levels of serum immunoglobulins leading to increased susceptibility to infections, potential autoimmune manifestations, and can be associated with gastrointestinal problems such as malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder triggered by consumption of gluten, found in wheat, barley, and rye, leading to inflammation and damage in the small intestines, malabsorption, and can delay puberty.

diagnoses.name: DiGeorge Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chromosomal disorder that results in poor development of several systems including immune system dysfunction leading to increased infections, potential delays in puberty due to hormonal imbalances, and can be associated with behavioral issues such as attention deficit.

diagnoses.name: Crohn’s Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory bowel disease that can cause malabsorption, leading to nutritional deficiencies affecting growth and development, potentially delaying puberty, and can increase susceptibility to infections due to complications or treatments.

diagnoses.name: Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by low levels of gonadotropin hormones, leading to delayed or incomplete puberty and can be associated with various systemic disorders, including those affecting the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder affecting the immune system’s ability to fight certain infections, leading to increased susceptibility to infections. It does not directly cause delayed puberty but can indirectly affect overall growth and development.

diagnoses.name: Shwachman-Diamond Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare congenital disorder characterized by exocrine pancreatic insufficiency leading to malabsorption, neutropenia leading to increased susceptibility to infection, skeletal abnormalities, and potential delay in puberty.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chromosomal disorder in females that leads to underdeveloped ovaries resulting in delayed or absent puberty, can be associated with an increased risk of autoimmune disorders, and may experience malabsorption or gastrointestinal issues.

diagnoses.name: Agammaglobulinemia
diagnoses.description: An X-linked or autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the absence or profound deficiency of immunoglobulins, leading to increased susceptibility to infections. It can be associated with enteropathy that causes malabsorption.

diagnoses: Neurological Disorders (e.g., Parkinson's Disease for blepharospasm)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can present with widespread symptoms, including hyperthermia (fever), alopecia, sensitivities, and varying degrees of pain.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, hyperthermia, sensitivities, and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.reasoning: MS can cause temperature sensitivity (Uhthoff's phenomenon), chronic pain, and can indirectly lead to fluctuations in blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition can cause joint pain, including in the back, and is associated with skin conditions (psoriasis) that might cause sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.reasoning: A rare tumor that can cause fluctuating blood pressure, episodic hyperthermia, and various systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism can cause hair loss, sensitivity to heat or cold, and impact blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Marked by severe fatigue, it can also present with a wide range of symptoms including sensitivities, hyperthermia, and pain.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause systemic symptoms including fever and chronic pain such as back pain, along with joint problems.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Early symptoms can include fever, hair loss, and sensitivities, progressing to chronic joint and back pain if untreated.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Primarily affects the spine, causing chronic back pain, and can have systemic effects like temperature sensitivity.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Coagulation disorders (e.g., Hemophilia, Vitamin K deficiency)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Conditions
diagnoses.description: Chronic inflammation can lead to poor healing, fibrosis, and can exacerbate conditions like lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Autoimmune conditions, such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis, can cause a wide variety of symptoms including poor healing, fibrosis, and angioedema due to the body's immune system attacking its own tissues.

diagnoses.name: Infections
diagnoses.description: Certain infections can lead to lymphadenitis (inflammation of the lymph nodes), poor healing, and potentially contribute to conditions that might mimic Kounis syndrome (a rare allergic reaction that affects the heart).

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders involving the dysfunctional proliferation or activity of mast cells can result in symptoms like angioedema and potentially poor healing. Mast cell activation syndrome (MCAS) is one such condition.

diagnoses.name: Cardiovascular Diseases
diagnoses.description: Certain cardiovascular diseases could theoretically exacerbate or contribute to conditions like Kounis syndrome, given its basis in inflammatory responses affecting the heart.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. It can cause fibrosis and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: Severe allergic reactions can lead to symptoms such as angioedema and, in rare cases, conditions like Kounis syndrome, which is an allergic reaction that affects the heart.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoproliferative Disorders
diagnoses.description: These are conditions in which lymphocytes are produced in excessive quantities. They may manifest through symptoms like lymphadenitis and could indirectly lead to issues with healing or fibrosis due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Connective Tissue Diseases
diagnoses.description: Diseases such as scleroderma or Marfan syndrome that affect the body's connective tissue can lead to fibrosis and poor healing.

diagnoses.name: Vascular Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions affecting the blood vessels, which may lead to angioedema or influence the development of conditions like Kounis syndrome if there is an underlying predisposition to allergic reactions affecting the cardiovascular system.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (including Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with cutaneous manifestation
Chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus (Discoid lupus erythematosus)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue in many parts of the body. Symptoms include lymphopenia, nonscarring alopecia, pleural effusion, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder affecting primarily joints but can also cause pleural effusion and pericarditis as systemic manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: A disease with features of several connective tissue diseases (including SLE and rheumatoid arthritis) that can cause nonscarring alopecia, lymphopenia, pleural effusion, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that cause the skin and connective tissues to harden and tighten. It can also lead to internal organ issues like pleural effusion and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that produce saliva and tears. It can have systemic effects resulting in lymphopenia and pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymphatic system. It can cause lymphopenia, pleural effusion, and nonscarring alopecia through various mechanisms.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) damages the immune system and can lead to acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) and lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can also lead to pleural effusion and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Can cause nonscarring alopecia and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium that is often due to a viral infection. It is usually associated with pericardial effusion.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Schizophrenia (for primary psychosis without underlying systemic condition)
